s.text: The DNA from one of these cells was then transferred into an unfertilized sheep egg cell from which they had carefully removed the DNA.
Cells in mature animal tissues are not, as we had thought, irreversibly differentiated.
As cells mature, however, they switch on some parts of those instructions, and switch off others.

As cells mature, however, they switch on some parts of those instructions, and switch off others.
Cells in mature animal tissues are not, as we had thought, irreversibly differentiated.
At one end of the black box you put in a simple cell, the fertilized egg, and out of the other you get a sheep, an earthworm, a human--a mature animal of staggering structural complexity.
As cells mature, however, they switch on some parts of those instructions, and switch off others.
Cells in mature animal tissues are not, as we had thought, irreversibly differentiated.
At one end of the black box you put in a simple cell, the fertilized egg, and out of the other you get a sheep, an earthworm, a human--a mature animal of staggering structural complexity.

But the mammary DNA that gave rise to Dolly became dedifferentiated , capable of generating the full range of different cell types that make up a sheep.

But the mammary DNA that gave rise to Dolly became dedifferentiated , capable of generating the full range of different cell types that make up a sheep.

(Unfertilized eggs contain only the mother's half of genes; by adding the genes from an adult mammary cell--which has both its mother's and father's genes--the egg cell then had the full amount of DNA found in adult sheep cells.)
We asked Andrew Berry, a geneticist, to explain how Dolly came into being, and why, from a biologist's point of view, she matters.)
